messages.content: Why did you suggest Golden Retriever for me? My answers: energyLevel=4, goodWithKids=5, trainability=5, shedding=2 dealbreaker accept

Golden Retrievers are heavy shedders so due to your dealbreaker they are excluded from your list. Other than that Golden Retrievers suite your preferrences - they are family friendly dogs that learn quickly and enjoy activities, they're highly affectionate, easy to train and they thrive with regular excercise - all of the things you prefer. Since you put a dealbreaker for shedding you shouldn't get a Golden Retriever if you're not ready to deal with hair everywhere.
Why did you suggest Barbado da Terceira for me? My answers: trainability=5, protectiveNature=5, barkingLevel=1, shedding=1, opennessToStrangers=4

The Barbado da Terceira is a medium-sized herding dog. Due to their intelligence, agility, strong work ethic and trainability they make a great match for you. Barbados are great protective dogs that are not as loud or vocal which suits your preferences perfectly, they are very eager to learn and barely shed. Only missmatch is that they are not as open to strangers as you'd want your ideal match to be. If that is something critical for you consider other breeds with a more social default.
Why did you suggest Poodle for me? match=86%, answers: goodWithKids=4, trainability=5, shedding=1 dealbreaker accept, livingEnvironment=urban

Poodles are highly trainable and adapt well to city life with daily mental work. Their curly coat aligns with your low-shedding dealbreaker but keep in mind that they still need regular professsional grooming or learn how to maintain their coat well at home. They’re generally really good with children when well socialized.
Why did you suggest Beagle for me? match=78%, answers: goodWithKids=5, goodWithOtherDogs=5, energyLevel=4, barkingLevel=2

Beagles are typically friendly with kids and other dogs and enjoy active play, which matches your energy preference. The only tension is barking: many Beagles are vocal scent hounds. If a quiet home is crucial, consider another more quite breed or give more training and enrichment to reduce baying.
Why did you suggest Basenji for me? match=74%, answers: barkingLevel=1, shedding=2, energyLevel=4, trainability=2

Basenjis are famously quiet and low-shedding, matching your noise and cleanup goals. They are energetic and need exercise but can be independent, so training may feel different than highly biddable breeds. Short, consistent sessions work best.
Why did you suggest Australian Shepherd for me? match=80%, answers: energyLevel=5, trainability=5, goodWithKids=5, livingEnvironment=suburban

Aussies are high-energy, very trainable, and generally good family dogs—great fit for an active suburban lifestyle. Plan for daily vigorous exercise and mental work. Seasonal shedding and regular brushing are part of the package.
Why did you suggest Barbado da Terceira for me? match=82%, answers: trainability=5, protectiveNature=5, barkingLevel=1, shedding=1

Barbado da Terceira combines strong trainability and a protective streak with relatively low shedding and modest vocalizing—close to your profile. They’re active herding dogs, so commit to structured exercise and jobs (training games, tasks) to keep them settled.
Why did you suggest Airedale Terrier for me? match=82%, answers: shedding=1 (dealbreaker accept), energyLevel=3–4, trainability=4, livingEnvironment=suburban.

Airedales shed minimally, satisfying your shedding dealbreaker. Their moderate-to-high energy and good trainability fit an active suburban routine. Plan for regular brushing and periodic professional grooming to keep the wiry coat in shape.
Why did you suggest Akita for me? match=79%, answers: protectiveNature=5 (dealbreaker accept), barkingLevel=2, livingEnvironment=suburban.

Your dealbreaker prioritizes strong guarding instincts, which Akitas have. Lower vocalizing and a suburban setting also align. Early socialization and consistent training are important, and expect seasonal heavy shedding.
Why did you suggest Basenji for me? match=76%, answers: barkingLevel=1 (dealbreaker accept), shedding=2, energyLevel=4.

You required a very quiet dog, and Basenjis are famously low-noise. Low-to-moderate shedding and higher energy match your profile. Keep training sessions short and engaging to work with their independent nature.
Why did you suggest American Bulldog for me? match=74%, answers: energyLevel=4 (dealbreaker accept), protectiveNature=4, livingEnvironment=suburban.

You asked for an athletic dog and made energy a dealbreaker. American Bulldogs thrive with daily activity and fit suburban living when exercised and trained consistently. Build in obedience work and skin-fold care as part of the routine.
Why did you suggest Afghan Hound for me? match=71%, answers: coatLength=long (dealbreaker accept), barkingLevel=2–3, livingEnvironment=suburban.

You required a long-coated breed, which Afghan Hounds are. Their generally modest vocalizing and suburban space can work well. Expect significant coat maintenance and keep them leashed or fenced due to strong chase instincts.
